                  "text": "Abstract. Self-organization can be broadly defined as the ability of a system to display ordered spatiotemporal patterns solely as the result of the interactions among the system components. Processes of this kind characterize both living and artificial systems, making self-organization a concept ...\n\nAbstract. Self-organization can be broadly defined as the ability of a system to display ordered spatiotemporal patterns solely as the result of the interactions among the system components. Processes of this kind characterize both living and artificial systems, making self-organization a concept that is at the basis of several disciplines, from physics to biology and engineering. Placed at the frontiers between disciplines, artificial life (ALife) has heavily borrowed concepts and tools from the study of self-organization, providing mechanistic interpretations of lifelike phenomena as well as useful constructivist approaches to artificial system design. Despite its broad usage within ALife, the concept of self-organization has been often excessively stretched or misinterpreted, calling for a clarification that could help with tracing the borders between what can and cannot be considered self-organization.\n\nHow a life-like system emerges from a simple particle motion law. ... Causal architecture, complexity and self-organization in time series and cellular automata. ... University of Wisconsin at Madison. ... The sciences of the artificial. ... Fifty years of research on self-replication: An overview. ... P. V. (Eds.) ( ... Self-organization: The quest for the origin and evolution of structure. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London Series A, ... Morphogenesis in robot swarms. ... Iterated learning: A framework for the emergence of language. ... Building agents out of autonomous behavior systems. In ... The artificial life route to artificial intelligence: Building embodied situated agents (pp. ... Lawrence Erlbaum. ... A self-organizing spatial vocabulary. ... G√©n√©alogies de l'auto-organisation. ... Spatial-pattern-induced evolution of a self-replicating loop network.\n\nThere are several other definitions of self-organization as well. [176] defines self-organization as an increase in statistical complexity, which in turn is defined as the amount of information required to minimally specify the state of the system's causal architecture.\n\nThere are several open questions that make for promising lines of research in the near future within ALife: ... How can self-organization be programmed? Self-organization relies on interactions (direct or indirect). Thus, it makes sense to focus on designing interactions to regulate and guide self-organization. Mediators [89, 132] can promote or constrain individual behaviors, precisely to achieve the proper interactions that will lead to the desired self-organization [64]. Information-theoretical approaches can also be used to program self-organization [111, 151]. Still, proposed approaches have been either too general or too specific. This makes it difficult to replicate successful self-organizing solutions beyond the original problems and remains an open challenge. ... Can the macroscopic outcomes of self-organization be predicted? Interactions in complex systems generate novel information that is not present in initial or boundary conditions, limiting predictability.",

                  "is_missing": false,
                  "text": "Self-organization is the fundamental core function of complex ecological systems. It is, in a sense, the underlying enabling function that makes all other functions possible. Stuart Kauffman (1995) has explored this function extensively and seeks its general principles. He says that order ‚Äúarises naturally and spontaneously because of these principles of self-organization‚Äîlaws of complexity that we are just beginning to understand.‚Äù ‚ÄúSelf-organization ‚Ä¶ may be the ultimate wellspring of [the] dynamical order‚Äù that underlies the origin, development, and operation of living systems. Several other prominent authors and researchers have explored the subject as well, in the context of a variety of both living systems and nonliving systems. A sampling is provided in the following paragraphs. Fritjof Capra (1996) notes that philosopher Immanuel Kant (in 1790) was ‚Äúthe first to use the term ‚Äòself-organization‚Äô to define the nature of living organisms.‚Äù Capra says the hallmark of self-organizat\n\nPaul Krugman (2008 Nobel laureate in economics and a professor at Princeton University) discusses the importance of the concept of self-organization‚Äîacross disciplines. In his book The Self-organizing Economy, Krugman (1996) says, ‚ÄúThe most provocative claim of the prophets of complexity is that complex systems often exhibit spontaneous properties of self-organization.‚Äù ‚ÄúI believe that the ideas of self-organization theory can add substantially to our understanding of the economy.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn the last few years the concept of self-organizing systems ‚Ä¶ has become an increasingly influential idea that links together researchers in many fields, from artificial intelligence to chemistry, from evolution to geology.‚Äù ... Self-organization is a key component of adaptive co-management, and refers to an approach wherein actors are immersed in collaborative and creative processes to solve problems and respond to disturbances (Armitage et al., 2007).\n\nIt may seem perverse that the study of complexity can lead us to simplicity. Yet ground-breaking research on self-organization during the late 1980s and 1990s appears to have done away with the tired idea of fitting the results of data-hungry models to sparse, observed data. Instead of the cumbersome drudgery of varying a large number of parameters and variables to obtain a better fit between the computed and observed data, models may again be used to develop and test new and exciting ideas. This is a dramatic shift in modeling philosophy. It comes about because models based on self-organization have the potential to develop ‚Äònew‚Äô knowledge about the systems they represent. Furthermore, this shift provides an opportunity to reevaluate the familiar conceptual tools in the geomorphological toolkit: for example, to move toward a new view of the function of positive and negative feedbacks in geomorphology and to a change in appreciation of the equilibrium concept (cf.\n\nIt may seem perverse that the study of complexity can lead us to simplicity.                   "type": "text",
                  "text": "‚Ç¨{¬ø‚Ç¨_Conversation_Analysis_and_language_learning.docx\n7.  L: I fight with my hand.\n\n8.  T: do you know karate?\n\n9.  L: I know karate.\n\n10. T: watch out guys, Wang knows karate.\n\n(Johnson 1995: 24)\n\n> The analysis will be divided into three stages. Firstly, what can we\n> say about the learner's actual developmental level or current ability\n> in L2? We can note in lines 3 and 5 that his grammatical resources are\n> fairly limited. Nonetheless, the learner is able to make use of these\n> limited resources to nominate a sub-topic (line 1), to develop the\n> sub-topic (line 3) and to turn the discussion to his own fighting\n> abilities (line 5). Although it can be challenging for children to\n> interact with the teacher in a classroom setting, even in the L1, we\n> can see that L is able to use the turn-taking and sequence\n> organisations of the L2 proficiently. L constantly needs to analyse\n> T's turns. From the learner's perspective, it is not just a matter of\n> understanding the propositional content of what T says in the L2; it\n> is also a matter of analysing what social and sequential action T is\n> performing and what an appropriate social and sequential action in\n> response would be. So we can see that L skilfully manages to\n> co-construct meaning with T in the L2 from his limited grammatical\n> resources.\n>\n> Secondly, what can we say about the learning environment in terms of\n> input to the language learning process and facilitation of upgrading\n> as a result of the interaction? Line 6 reads: 'you know how to fight\n> with your hands?' We will break its contribution down into four\n> points. Firstly, the utterance places the sequence within the\n> teacher's overall pedagogical plan for the lesson, which 'was to allow\n> the students to share their ideas and possibly generate some new\n> vocabulary words within the context of the discussion' (Johnson 1995:\n> 23). Secondly, it may promote positive affect and motivation in that\n> the teacher engages with the ideas and personal meanings which the\n> learner chooses to share and produces a conversational action of\n> confirmation check which validates the utterance. Line 6 also displays\n> interest in the learner's extra-curricular abilities. It then\n> demonstrates confidence in the learner by returning the floor to him\n> with the question. Thirdly, it makes it possible for the other\n> learners in the class to follow the topic of the interaction (the\n> others are explicitly addressed in line 10) and to receive correctly\n> formed linguistic input. There is no evidence in the transcripts as to\n> whether the other learners have done so or not. However, Ohta (2001)\n> shows (by recording and transcribing the private talk of individually\n> microphoned students in a classroom) that students are capable of\n> using recasts in which they are not personally involved as negative\n> evidence and of displaying uptake in their private talk.",
